instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.P1V8S3_EN: What is P1V8S3_EN? P1V8S3_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V8_S3 line when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
the board no water damage, it came with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> near SMC i was fix the short and reball the SMC.
now green and orange light but no fan and nothing on SMC bypass.
3V42 - 3.4v
PPBUS - 8.6v
PPVRTC - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.0v
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> -3.3v
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0.8v-1.3v playing up and down
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0.2v - 0.4v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 0.8v-1.3v playing up and down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
Do you mean pulsing every 5s?

Check for short all big coils; see if pulse too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
"Do you mean pulsing every 5s?"
No up and down all the time from 0.5v to 2.1v <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> a littel bit lower...cant find short on big coils

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
Monitor <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> signal.
Post ALL RTC voltage, not only power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
"Monitor <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> signal" i dont have scope. voltage on  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0v-1.9v runing.

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V stable.
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V stable.
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_PCH_DCPRTC</SIGNAL> 1.3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> 0.4(<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> LEG 12)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
"ALL RTC"
Still missing some; look at PCH's RTC block connections...
Post <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>.

"i dont have scope"
Not really needed; voltmeter is good enough.

Also post <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>.

Mention any signal which not stable, fluctuating...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 2.9v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.1v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.1v
all stable
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0.6v to 2v runing up and down. pulses

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> fluctuates, then <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> should fluctuate too.
Also check what happen with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/4/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> - runing slow from 0.2v to 0.6v loop not...all 3 exectly the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
An o-scope is better; it can catch peak value of any pulse.
Check if S3/0 voltages fluctuates too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message: There is few S3/0 missing voltage  and few fluctuates

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
Check if missing ones have fluctuation on corresponding enable signal.
Also check for short on them.

I don't remember if you tried SMC bypass mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green/orange light OK, no FAN spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> AND <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_EN</SIGNAL>  - 0V-0.2V LOOPS
<SIGNAL>TBTAPWRSW_ISET_S3_R</SIGNAL> 0V STABLE
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> - 0V-0.3V LOOPS
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_RC</SIGNAL> - 0V-0.4V LOOPS
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_D</SIGNAL> 0V STABLE
<SIGNAL>SMC_1V2S3_ISENSE</SIGNAL> - 0V STABLE
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_FET_R</SIGNAL> 0V-0.2V LOOPS
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4RS3_VFB1</SIGNAL> - 0.9V-1.4V LOOPS
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4RS3_FUNC</SIGNAL> - 0V STABLE
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 0.1V-0.2V
<SIGNAL>PPVTT_S3_DDR_BUF</SIGNAL> - 0V STABLE
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.2V-0.6V LOOPS
<SIGNAL>P1V8S3_EN</SIGNAL> 0.1V-0.5V LOOPS
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 0.2V-0.5V LOOPS

S0:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.2V-0.9V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.2V-0.9V
<SIGNAL>TBTAPWRSW_ISET_S0</SIGNAL> - 0V STABLE
<SIGNAL>SMC_P1V05S0_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 0V STABLE
<SIGNAL>ISNS_P3V3S0_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 0V STABLE


reset SMC do nothing
